Since dice are never removed from the game and their values are continuously re-randomized in a way that is largely beyond player influence, this effectively means the winner of the game is chosen at random among the remaining players.

33118.name: Commonwealth Navy
33118.description:
From the Rules: The game is intended to be a representation of Target practice as carried out by the Navy; the figured squares in the centre of the board representing the Target, and the shaded squares around the edge of the board representing the course taken by the competing Ships.

The ships always move one square at a time, along the course, in a clockwise direction. The four squares, colored Red, Blue, Green, and Yellow are the starting points, or Stations, from which the Ships commence their practice.Each player in turn rolls the die or spins the teetotem and counts the number in following the arrow. If the end result is a square with a number the player score that value and then moves to the next square.

When all players have gone through 36 stations the player with the highest score wins.

33119.description:
In September 1816, San Martín relocated his Army of the Andes to Plumerillo, in the northern part of Mendoza Province, where he finished the details to start his crossing of the Andes. The army was divided in two main columns and four minor ones, keeping the decided paths in secret.

On January 18, 1817, a main column parted with the artillery to Chile through Uspallata, under command of General Las Heras, reaching Las Cuevas on February 1, 1817. The second main column led by San Martín, left on January 19 through Los Patos pass, and reached San Andrés de Tártaro on February 8, where he was later joined by Las Heras, concluding the first part of the crossing.

The crossing of the Andes took twenty-one days. It was an extremely difficult enterprise, with temperatures ranging from 30° Celsius during the day to -10° Celsius at night, altitudes averaging 3000 meters above sea level, and paths that were far from being roads appropriate for an army: they consisted of a 50 cm wide paths mainly used by locals for traveling on mules, with several passages which had to be crossed literally in single file. Besides all those hardships, San Martín was far from healthy and was carried on a stretcher during most of the trip. By the end of crossing, around 300 men — 5.5% of the total at the beginning — had lost their lives, mostly due to the harsh conditions of the trip.

In 1817, he crossed the Andes from Mendoza to Chile, and prevailed over the Spanish forces after the Battle of Chacabuco and Battle of Maipú (1818), liberating Chile together with Chilean Bernardo O'Higgins.

The game recreat the cross of the Andes by San Martin´s army. In this game the patriot player wins by controlling chile´s cities in less than 20 turns, and the royalist player wins preventing the patriot´s objetive. There are special rules about movement in high altitude and patriot´s surprise factor.
33119.name: Campaña de los Andes

33120.name: Rommel's Obsession
33120.description:
Rommel's Obsession is a block game that covers the 1941 battle for Tobruk and the British counterattack known as "Operation Crusader". The Axis had besieged Tobruk and were holding the Halfaya Pass into Egypt. The Allies launched a wide sweeping offensive through the open desert with the goal of relieving Tobruk. This is a battle with no clearly defined front line. Historically, British and Axis formations criss-crossed each other in bewildering patterns.

Blocks in this game are mostly regiments and brigades and each turn represents two days time. Great effort has been made to duplicate the feel and decisions the commanders faced in the battle. Smart aggressiveness is rewarded. The Germans have the superior units, but the Commonwealth can more readily replace losses. Victory is determined not only by possession of territory, but by those casualties.

Why call it Rommel’s Obsession?
Tobruk became the focal point of Rommel’s attention, both during the time span of this game and the following year. As historian W.G.F. Jackson describes Rommel’s mindset before this battle,

“Contemporary evidence suggests that Rommel became more and more obsessed with the problems of attacking Tobruk and refused to accept the possibility of the British forestalling him.”

Before the battle began, Italian proclamations that the British were about to attack were dismissed as “excessive Latin nervousness.” Indeed, even after the battle began, Rommel refused to believe that it was anything more than a reconnaissance in force. He only changed his mind when he heard an announcement of the offensive on a British radio broadcast out of Cairo! It was this mindset that led to some of the unique circumstances of this battle.

33121.description:
The World War:

Without an exact translation this is an estimation of the actual rules. The games main mechanic is jumping other pieces and is a game for 2 or more players.

Each side gets 30 pieces. Alternatively each player puts one piece (name tag down) on an enemy land square. Once all the pieces have been placed they are moved alternately either to an adjacent empty space or by jumping over an adjacent piece; multiple jumps can be made as long as empty spaces exist. As each piece makes its first move it is turned upright so that the name shows. If a player is able to get a piece to the city on the map that matches the name tag of the piece then he turns it back over to signify it no longer moves.

If a player can be the first to have only his units present in cities of his home country then the game ends and that player is declared the winner.
33121.name: Der Weltkrieg

33122.name: Wonder Go
33122.description:
Award-winning WonderGo is a wonder-filled introduction to the greatest strategy game of Asia. Intellectually and culturally advantageous for children, playing WonderGo involves strategic thinking, concentration, visualization, plus lots of fun and surprise as hidden prizes are discovered inside the innovative game pieces (aka WonderGo Stones).

Dr. Toy - Best Products Award - 2007!

Creative Child Magazine - Game of the Year Award - 2007!

Contents: 24page, illustrated, WonderGo Lesson Book; 48 jumbo-sized, "prize-fillable", WonderGo stones; 16" tri-fold gameboard; 1 set of motivational sticker prizes; 2 WonderReward Cards (incentive charts); and game rules.

33123.name: Matrix
33123.description:
Matrix is an older boardgame from 1954 based on classical mathematical game theory of games with simultaneous selection of actions from a payoff matrix. The game has 2 phases:

First the two players (or 1 player vs several, in a multi-player variant) first take turns placing their 8 tiles valued 1, 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7 on a 4x4 square grid to create a payoff matrix which will be more favorable for them than for the opponent. Then they simultaneously choose a row and column of that payoff matrix to earn points, i.e. directly playing a classical game theoretic game, until one side reaches 25 points.

The multi-player variant in fact gives no upper bound on the number of players, but the example uses 4 players.

33124.name: The Liberty Game
33124.description:
The Liberty game was created at the end of WWI and what follows is based on examining the only part available, the game board.

Apparently the player moves along the path via a die roll, fighting against the color coded units the player lands on (possibly facing at least 3 levels of combat, each new challenge coming after winning a previous battle). Each victory earns points.

The assumption is that after all players have returned to the USA the player with the most points wins.

33125.name: Blasphemy
33125.description:
In Blasphemy you take part in the fate of a would-be Messiah. Your aim is to convince your compatriots that your Jesus, and your Jesus alone, is the genuine article.

To accomplish this, your Jesus must cut as impressive a figure as possible. He must give stirring sermons, perform miracles, attract devoted followers, and generally carry on in a Messiah-like fashion. Your Jesus must make every effort to discredit his rivals, and in the end, he must get himself killed. Yes, alas, the price of fame was dear in those days. It was clearly written that the Messiah would come to a sticky end. Accordingly, you win the game if you're the first player to get your Jesus nailed up. Blasphemy is the race to the cross!

33126.name: Ankeborgsloppet
33126.description:
Ankeborgsloppet

Age: Ages 5 and up

Follow Donald Duck and his friends around the board game. You have to have luck on your side to reach the finish line first. Easy to learn.

Content:
1 Board game
6 pieces of wood
1 Dice

33127.name: Alfa-Lek
33127.description:
A game in Kärnan´s line of wooden games for children.

This is an educational game to help children learn to read and write. The game features 56 wooden-puzzle tiles with letters. Players connect tiles to make the letters build words matching.

Ages 7 and up.

33128.name: Bankrott de Luxe
33128.description:
(english translation: "Bancruptcy Deluxe")

Similar to Go For Broke. The players start with 1 Million Dollars each, trying to lose all their money as fast as possible with gambling, speculation, betting etc.

Lots of luck elements, like dice and a collection of spinners.
Was published as a game of the Schmidt Spiele-Bar series in book case format.

33129.name: CSz!
33129.description:
CSz! is a card game based on ComedySportz (the interactive improvised comedy show franchise). Each player represents a team of ComedySportz performers (Actletes), each one with their own strengths and weaknesses.

The game is divided into the same rounds performed at ComedySportz shows. Players try to earn modifier points by having their Actletes make funny offers during improv games. Offers can be good or bad, and they can be played by either player on a given Actlete.

At the end of each round, players roll to see who the audience votes for, modifying their die rolls with the points they have accumulated.

The game is designed to recreate the experience involved in putting on a ComedySportz show (not necessarily the experience of a show itself). Actlete cards are based on real performers from various ComedySportz cities around the country.

Each Actlete has 5 attributes, and 11 points to divide up among the attributes (they must be between 1 and 3). Veteran Actletes get an additional point.

33130.description:
An imagination, memory and storytelling game.

Arthur's stories are waiting to be discovered and shared! Find your five matching story tiles, arrange the tiles from left to right, and tell the story you have created.

This is two games in one - Memory and storytelling.

Contents: 50 square story tiles
10 rectangle character tiles
33130.name: Arthur's Game

33132.name: Benedicto
33132.description:
Benedicto, also know as "Beat the Blitz". An odd little follow-the-path game created by the makers of Benedict Peas. The description says it is a thrilling race against air raids, and time bombs, road jams and tank traps, warnings and diversions.

Players start in the pea patch and must move through the factory as they head home. The most interesting parts of the game are the advertisements on the back.

33133.name: Bomber Raid
33133.description:
From the rules: The object of the game is to bomb enemy objectives and, at the same time, to spot and bring down attacking enemy bombers before they drop their bombs. Equipment includes the game board, two dice, 2 searchlight beams and 8 bombers.

Players place the searchlight on the board with the small end on the X about the searchlight crew and the large end pointing to the 1. Play is alternately done and is based on the roll of a die. The roll can be used to either move a plane or the searchlight. A roll of 6 means the player loses his turn. Planes may be moved in any direction but must be moved the full distance of the die roll in that same direction. The searchlight can be moved in one direction, up or down, based on the die roll. A plane is shot down when either it is on the same line as an enemy airplane at the end of the enemy's turn or it crosses the searchlight beam. A score is obtained if the plane can cross over the targets in enemy territory.

The winner is the player with the highest bombing total after all planes have been brought down.

33134.name: Define It
33134.description: The box describes this game as an "extraordinary new concept" and a "unique fun-filled word game fashioned for the family of the future". Develop your verbal abilities, comprehension, pronunciation, and vocabulary.

33135.name: Strategy
33135.description:
Strategy is played by two players. Each player has 12 units which are put into play from the black circles at opposite end s of the board called the "Front Line". The spinner controls the movement of the units.

Players spin alternately and if they land on a numeral they can move the number of units indicated diagonally one space per unit. Special spins (left and right gun) kill all enemy units along the appropriate gun line. Also the charged wire spin kills all units sitting on the wire. The fill spin allows you to bring in one of the replacement units. Players can also jump enemy units to capture them.

The winner is the first player to get a unit into the enemy "First Line".

33137.name: Closing the Ring
33137.description:
From the "Pledge" link on the Decision Games Website:

This mid-sized-monster game can be played as a two-player or three-player contest. It has three large-hex maps, with 560 half-inch counters, covering the ETO from D-Day to V-E Day at 20 miles per hex. The main fronts are covered, excluding only Scandinavia and Greece. Each game turn equals a third of a month. Units are divisions for the Western Allies and Germans, corps for the Soviets (but with a complete divisional artillery order of battle), and armies for the Yugoslav's and the various minor powers.

The system is an operational (rather than strategic) derivation of the one used in "Beyond the Urals" and "Operation Kremlin." No unit will have more than one step. All entry data, notes about reinforcement or special status, etc., can be printed on their reverse sides. Stacking is eight units per hex, with both sides having the move/fight or fight/move sequence option, along with the possibility for limited use of fight/fight.

The system will be simple, making for a game players can finish in one long weekend, but there will also be plenty of historic chrome, such as: V-weapons, the Warsaw Rebellion, liberation of the death camps, Führer-Mandated Offensives, FLAK divisions, the Upper Silesian industrial region, German economic collapse, National Socialist ardor, proletarian heroism, heavy bombers, naval gun support, fortified lines, etc.

Play begins with the Western Allied player (or the "Grand Alliance" player in a two-player match) launching the D-Day landing. He'll be free to choose just about any coastal hex from northern Germany to the Spanish border as his landing site. Or he might choose to come ashore that first time on the Mediterranean coast of France, the far north of Italy, or even somewhere along the Yugoslavian coast. He'll also have a second invasion available for use later that summer.

Victory is determined using a point system, primarily based on the German retention of cities according to a schedule derived from the historic Allied advance. There will be periodic victory checks to prevent the German player from adopting any kind of unhistorical strategy based on retreating into the Reich's heartland at the very start of play to try to form some kind of super defensive hedgehog. That ploy would have been impossible for the Germans to support economically in the real-world, and having to maintain a certain level of victory points in order to survive the period victory checks will work to the same effect in the game.

The combat results table will be of the unit-elimination type, with results of "D-elim," "D-back-2," "Exchange," etc. Thus replacements will be plentiful and the action along the fronts fast and furious. Typical German infantry division will have attack and defense factors of 1-1, 1-2 or 2-3, while panzer divisions will weigh in as 3-2s and 4-3s. In comparison, US infantry divisions will be 3-4s, while that nation's armor divisions will be 4-3s and 5-3s.

A boxed game to be designed by Ty Bomba. Est. Retail: $60 (Est. Pledge: $45)

33138.name: The Big Battalions
33138.description:
A Napoleonic Game suitable for several brigades on each side.

Can be played with 28mm down to 6mm figures. Infantry are based on 40mm squares for 25/8mm and 25mm squares for 15mm down to 6mm. Units are battalions, squadrons or batteries. Games are usually up to a Corps per side with two players.

Card driven with the numbers of cards and options available being dependent on the quality of the commander. Combat is abstracted in "DBx" style depending on the number of units involved and support rather than detailed firing and melee results.

Movement and range measurement is also very flexible being determined by "bands" of distance (around 6" in a 25mm game) rather than micro measurement.

National characteristics and morale rules cover all aspects of the Napoleonic period. Designed for rapid action and big decisions rather than micro management. And no casualty removal so all those lovely 28mm figures that you painted stay on display!

33139.description:
An expansion for Metric Mile from Jeff Packe and Terry Goodchild that adds 50 milers to the original set - 36 new, 12 revisions to milers in the original, and a 2-runner 'freebie' of Jeff Packe's personal picks as threats for the World Championship.

Also, the four milers that were issued with Replay Report (newsletter) have been re-worked and included with the 36 new milers, instead of the Revised set.

Expands:

Metric Mile
33139.name: More Metric Milers

33140.name: Hyper Slide
33140.description: Be quick as you flick, slide or shoot the different-colored hyper discs under the arch. As the game unit calls out the sequence of colors for you to pass, the game knows if you've passed the right disc or not. Pass 'em fast before the buzzer blasts! Obey the voice commands, get your brain in the game and break the code, or guess which color will be called next. Play with a friend or practice solo. Tabletop slide-and-pass excitement features electronic lights and sounds, plus an announcer's voice that talks you through three fast-sliding game modes. Electronic game unit comes with four Hyper Discs, each a different color; plus Hyper Band and instructions.

33141.name: Castle Croquetnole
33141.description:
The ingenuity of man has never conceived anything better calculated to bring out all the evil passions of humanity than the so-called game of Croquet. It is not long before every honorable feeling, every dictate of morality has been obliterated. The hoop is the gaping jaws of hades.

Living Age magazine, 1898, quoted in The New Games Treasury, Merilyn Simonds Mohr, 1997

An adaptation of Lewis Carroll's game Castle Croquet. Each player brings his knight out of his castle by playing it through its castle's gate, and 'invading' the other castles with it in the proper sequence. He then re-enters his own castle and hits his tower, while his own guard is 'on duty'. The first player to do so wins.

33142.name: Space Cruiser Yamato
33142.description:
This game makes "Space Cruiser Yamato" of the animated cartoon work a radical.
This game is if Seriesof bandai's boardgame.
this game is a board of the strategy class in the world of Yamato.
This game appear "Battleship, cruiser, destroyer, guided-missile-cruiser, aircraft carrier, fighter, bomber,
and torpedo bomber, etc." .


Components
map 3(590x228)
unit 447
rulebook
Scenario Book
player aid card 1
Ship Log sheet 1
Aircraft Log Sheet 1
dice 2



Yes, it's true. This game DOES make Space Cruiser Yamato of the animated cartoon work a radical.

33143.name: This War Without An Enemy
33143.description: Andy Ogden's game of the first English Civil War, loosely based on Hannibal: Rome versus Carthage, features split-action Event/Strategy cards, extensions of the the Battle card system for resolving field engagements and new siege/assault rules for investing major and minor fortresses.

33144.name: Brainstonz
33144.description:
Complete a row of four stones in a vertical, horizontal or diagonal line. Each turn, place two stones on the board or remove an opponent's stone if your stones are on twin symbols.

Polished river stones are used as the pieces. The wooden board, which is a 4x4 grid, also contains a drawer for holding the stones.

Contains rules in English, French and Spanish.

A hockey themed version named "BrainPucks", licensed by the NHL, also exists. Instead of using abstract symbols, players match hockey team logos

33145.name: Cardinal's Guards
33145.description:
A Solitary Confinement game for the piecepack

The year is 1626, and France is under the control of Cardinal Richelieu. The King and Queen are weak, and there is no love lost between the King’s musketeers and the Cardinal’s guards. In a castle in Normandy, four musketeers have just broken out of solitary confinement. The castle is well garrisoned, with a full company of the Cardinal’s guards, but the musketeers are determined to locate evidence of the Cardinal’s treachery against the King, that they know is somewhere within the castle. They form a plan; each musketeer will search a different set of particular halls and chambers, and then attempt to escape from the castle while defeating as many guards as possible. Hopefully the musketeer with the evidence will reach the King. The task ahead won’t be easy, but there is hope, and the musketeers have knowledge of a secret network of underground passages beneath the castle that the guards are unaware of.

In Cardinal’s Guards, the player moves the musketeers around the castle, defeating or luring guards, while searching various chambers, before trying to escape.


The musketeers are represented by the four pawns.
The coins represent the guards.
The tiles represent castle chambers.
The dice are used to keep track of the chambers searched.


The player’s score at the end of the game is based upon the number of chambers searched, the number of guards defeated, and the number of musketeers who escape.

33146.name: Fantastic Four Encounter With Doom
33146.description: Choose either the Fantastic Four or Doctor Doom. Use your attack cards to wipe out your opponent's hit points or your strategy cards to attack multiple times. Defend cards are your only way to hold on to those hit points!

33147.description:
Monopoly Junior, Disney Channel Edition is a remake of the original Monopoly game with a new, fun theme. Choose your favorite Disney Channel character and race around the gameboard buying properties as you go. Did you buy The Suite Life with Zack and Cody or Kim Possible? Maybe you bought Jump In! or The Cheetah Girls. If someone lands on a property you own, they'll have to pay you! But watch out for Ms. Darbus and Dr. Drakken. Land on them and you'll have to pay. Collect the most money by the end of the game and you win!

This game is designed for children ages 5-8 and comes with the gameboard, 48 plastic televisions, 24 chance cards, 1 pack of play money, 8 character pawns, 4 stands, 1 Die and instructions.
33147.name: Monopoly Junior: Disney Channel

33148.name: Z.O.D.
33148.description:
Epic battle of "Z" forces VS "D" forces.

Competing corporate powers fight for supremecy in urban ruins, with infantry, tanks, aircraft and large robots. New sets can be added, expanding the troop choices and the size of the battlefield.

Box set comes with:
- 18-20 high quality figures (3 sets available):
1 set: 10 marines, 6 mechs (4 heavy armed and 2 light), 2 fighters,
2 set: 10 marines, 6 mechs (4 heavy armed and 2 light), 3 tanks, 1 rocket forces tank,
3 set: 10 marines, 6 mechs (2 heavy armed and 4 light), 2 tanks, 1 special tank.
All mechs in all sets are different. Marines not T_T

Also every set includes:
- Ruined buildings constructor (40-60 high quality pieces),
- 2 1d6 dices,
- 1 special dice,
- 40 counters (used with armlists),
- 20 camouflage counters (marines only),
- Instructions for ruined buildings assembly,
- Instructions for figures assembly,
- Tips for painting,
- 2 reference sheets,
- Battlefield board,
- Unit cards (aka armlists),
- Scenarios book (4 different scenarios per set),
- 12-page rulebook .

http://www.tehnolog.ru/product/zod/

33149.name: At All Hazards: The Cold Harbor Campaign
33149.description: Division-level game covering the Cold Harbor campaign of 1864 (American Civil War).

33150.description: Cranium WOW includes an all new gameboard, 600 new cards with 15 fun activities (we promise), a 10-sided die (the 9-sided die just wasn't working), a tub of lovely, lovely cranium clay, a timer, pads, pencils, 4 new character movers with custom hats and hairdos, and sass. Cranium is a roll and move game with four distinct decks of cards that have the players perform, answer trivia, sculpt, and use their knowledge of popular culture to advance through the board to the center. It is a very fun game and is designed for adults, or people who are "adult-like".
33150.name: Cranium WOW

33151.name: Robots and Reptiles
33151.description:
Robots and Reptiles is a war game played on a checker board or other grid based map. Players build their forces around miniatures they provide, which could be anything from plastic army men to Godzilla figurines. This was a Cheap Ass style game from the age of mimeographs, before photocopies were plentiful and cheap.

This stand alone product has sample units and rules for creating your own, and the rules book is small enough to fit in your pocket.

Many copies have incomplete or hard to read rules because they were all trimmed in bulk, by hand, so partial text clipping is common.

33152.name: Hollywood Shuffle
boardgamepodcastepisode: OBG 018: The Culture of Game Consumption
33152.description: Players cast, title, and add their own Hollywood endings to over 200,000 jumbled movie plots. Players vote on their favorite answers and try to match each answer to the other players. Correct matches and most favorite votes move players' pawns forward on the board. First player to the end wins.

33153.name: Game of SIM
33153.description:
The Game of Sim is a paper and pencil game played by two players, Red and Blue, using six dots ('vertices') arranged in a hexagon. Players alternately draw a line between two dots. The first player to draw a triangle of their color between three dots loses.

The game cannot end in a tie. 15 moves is the maximum. If the game actually lasts 15 moves then the loser will actually complete two triangles at once!

Simmons, Gustavus J. "The game of SIM," J. Recreational Mathematics, 2(2), 1969, pp. 66.

Gardner, M. Mathematical Games, Scientific American, February (1973), pp. 108-112

E. Mead, A Rose, C, Huang, The Game of SIM: A Winning Strategy for the Second Player, Mathematical Report No. 58, 1973, McMaster University.

L.E.Shader, Another Strategy for SIM, Mathematics Magazine, Vol. 51. No. 1, pp. 60-62, 1978.

boardgamehonor: 2009 Golden Geek Best Board Game Artwork/Presentation Nominee
2009 Golden Geek Best Family Board Game Nominee
2009 JoTa Best Artwork Nominee
2009 JoTa Best Family Board Game Nominee
33154.description:
Wasabi! is a light and fast game where you compete against other players to assemble your quota of unique sushi recipes in a rapidly dwindling space. Players draw a variety of delicious ingredients into their hand from the pantry and play them one at a time onto the board, building off of each other's previously-placed ingredients in the attempt to complete recipes of varying difficulty.

Completing a recipe earns you your choice of special actions from the kitchen to perform later (Chop!, Stack!, Switch!, Spicy!, and the dreaded Wasabi!) that will help you in your efforts or disrupt your opponents' carefully arranged creations-in-progress.

Completing a recipe with style will earn you bonus points, but you might not always have the time to set up such stylish maneuvers... balancing speed with technique will be crucial if you plan to win the game!

Victory comes as soon as the board fills up with ingredients. Points for completed recipes plus bonuses are tabulated, and the winner is the player with the most points. An extremely skilled player might score an instant victory by completing their quota of recipes before the board fills up.
33154.name: Wasabi!
boardgamefamily: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGB Volume 64 - Session Reviews: Ghost Stories, Wasabi, and Gem Dealer
The Spiel #68 - That's A Wrap - 2008 Holiday Gift Guide

33155.description:
Welcome to sunny Gopher Gulch, home of a unique gopher population known far and wide for their bright and colorful coats! Due to their particular diets, our local gophers have developed fur in remarkable shades of red, purple, and orange… this is a sight that has to be seen to be believed, and every season we get bus after bus of excited tourists like yourself, eager to see our little furry friends! Quite a few Gopher Ranchers have set up shop around town, and each of them will try to show you exactly what you’ve come to see. Thanks for visiting Gopher Gulch, please remember to tell your friends!

~The Gopher Gulch Tourism Board

Players are gopher ranchers in the town of Gopher Gulch, each placing tiles to build their own warren of burrows, hoping to attract all three types of gophers. It’s a delicate balancing act where every tile counts. Build your warren, forming burrows of three different colors. Complete a burrow of a particular color that is longer than the current shortest burrow in that color, and the gopher living there moves into the new one; it stays there until it gets lured away again by an even bigger burrow! There is one less gopher of each color than there are players, so not everyone will be able to host all three gopher types at once.

Every once in a while the tour bus will arrive, and the tourists will be most excited to see the types of gophers promised to them by their tour schedule. If your ranch is missing those particular gophers, you’ll get complaints from the tourists. At the end of the tourist season, the rancher with the fewest complaints wins!
33155.name: Burrows

33156.description:
Magnet won 2010 Runner Up Abstract Game of the Year in Games Magazine.

An abstract game where players try to get their king to the middle of the board. Each player has 12 blocks, 11 of which can be promoted 1, 2, or 3 times, thus increasing their movement capability (the king cannot be promoted so don't promote all your other pieces, or you will give away your king's location). A "magnet," a black pawn, is placed on a gridded point and affects all of a player's pieces on lines radiating out from that point, moving them closer to the magnet. You can capture other pieces in this way, removing them from the board.
33156.name: Magnet

33157.name: Aviation Tycoon
33157.description: In Aviation Tycoon, players buy stock in four airline companies as they fly passengers across various airline routes. When an airline route is used, that airline gets paid. When dividends are paid, those with stock get paid — and keep getting paid until the airline has no money left (assuming the funds can be easily divided among the shareholders). Special event cards can close airports, double payouts for using routes, etc. Special player cards give each player access to a special ability (which all share during a round).

33158.description:
Part of the Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition line.

This is a set of maps and counters, along with turn gauges suitable for miniature play and the 'Section W' miniature rules for Star Fleet Battles.

From the publisher:

Large 46x38 inch map with 1.25" hexes, double the normal size! Suitable for miniatures (SFB or any other game) or huge battles with regular counters. Also includes full-color planets, moons, asteroids, and a comet printed on the same size hex grid so you can arrange whatever terrain you need. (Includes one five-hex planet, two three-hex planets, a two-hex planet, and numerous one-hex planets. The comet is four hexes long.) Also includes miniatures turn gauges and firing arc templates and "tabletop" (non-hex) rules.
33158.name: Star Fleet Battles: Module W – Space Battle Maps

33159.description:
A fast card game where players blind bid for dynasty cards such as warriors, nobles, bureaucrats, peasants, and merchants. You must balance your claims to score well at the end. There are special cards gotten from having the most in a category that give you a bonus, often affecting the bidding process. For example, the Palace lets you see all bids before placing yours and the Heir lets you claim an unclaimed dynasty card.

From back of the box:

Following the collapse of the Han Dynasty, warlords backed rival claimants to the Chinese Throne, while others sought influence among the merchants, nobles, farmers, and bureaucrats.

Each round, players play Bid Cards to claim Dynasty Cards and take control of the Emperor, Heir, Palace, Market, and Harvest. However, the heavens in the guise of a Celestial Dragon, can disrupt the best laid plans. The game ends as the Emperor dies and whoever gains the most influence will ascen the throne.
33159.name: Middle Kingdom

boardgamehonor: 2009 Golden Geek Best Gamers' Board Game Nominee
2009 Meeples' Choice Award
2010 As d'Or - Jeu de l'Année Nominee
2010 Golden Geek Best Strategy Board Game Nominee
2010 Hra roku Nominee
2010 International Gamers Awards - General Strategy; Multi-player Nominee
2010 JoTa Best Family Board Game Nominee
2010 Juego del Año Tico Nominee
2010 Spiel des Jahres Recommended
2010 Tric Trac d'Argent
2010 Tric Trac Nominee
33160.description:
It is a time when the maps of the world are still being filled in. Seagoing empires expand their frontiers by sending ships to the farthest reaches of the globe in search of new lands, new alliances, and new conquests. The wealth of the newly-discovered worlds abroad is a tempting prize for those with the strength and the cunning to seize it... and to hold it!
You represent a growing empire engaged in a glorious endeavor to expand your
influence and status at home and across the great oceans of the world. Through exploration and shipping, colonization and war, you will struggle with the other great powers to control the resources and the regions that unfold before you.

The goal in Endeavor is to earn the most glory for your empire. Players earn glory by increasing their scores in Industry, Culture, Finance, and Politics, as well as by occupying cities, controlling connections between cities, and by holding certain Asset Cards and Building Tiles. Short-term goals of constructing useful buildings, gathering Trade Tokens, and obtaining Asset Cards must be balanced with the overall goal of attaining glory as you compete for control over the various regions of the world. The game only lasts seven rounds, and when it is over you want to be the one who has earned the most Glory points!

Each round every player gets to build a new building, based on their Industry track. They then obtain new population markers based on their Culture track and retrieve used markers from building based on their Finance track. During the action phase, players take turns to either activate a building using a population marker or spend trade tokens to take an action: Ship, Occupy, Attack, Payment or Draw. Some buildings and tokens allow a player to take one or both of two actions. Shipping is used to open new regions for Occupation and Drawing, and gains you Trade Tokens. Once a shipping track is full, the player with the most influence in that region gains the powerful Governor card for that region. Occupation of a city results in glory and Trade Tokens, while Attacking steals a city from an opponent! Either Occupation or Attacking can result in claiming the connection between two cities, if both connected cities are controlled by the same player. Drawing gains a card from a region up to the maximum hand limit based on the player's Politics track. A player's influence in a region determines which cards they can draw. Once all players have passed, a new round begins.
33160.name: Endeavor
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGA Ep. 36 - Imperial Settlers, Power Grid, Endeavor, & Friday the 13th
Carnagecast 24: David Cheng of the Schenectady Wargamers Association and Endeavor
Episode 27: Broom Service Review - Questions from a Hat
MOBG 34 Good cop, Bad Pingo Pingo
The Good, The Board and The Guru:  Episode 42 “Trent’s Top 10″
보톡스(Boardgame Talks) 제24회 - 엔데버(Endeavor, Magister Navis), Francis Tresham

33161.name: Clear!
33161.description:
A game for the piecepack.

Equipment:

Each player requires:

* 6 piecepack tiles (doesn’t matter which ones)
* 4 piecepack dice
* 24 coins from one piecepack (all 4 suits, null/2-5/ace each suit)
* opaque bag, cup, or other means of mixing 24 piecepack coins for random drawing

One player is designated the scorekeeper. That person needs:

* notepad and pencil, or some other scorekeeping mechanism
* an additional piecepack tile
* 3 pawns

Object: Score the most points after a predetermined number of rounds (7 rounds makes an excellent game). Object of each round is to be one of the first players to clear your card.

This game is very similar to Bingo in the sense that each player possesses a “card,” which one marks based on a random element. In this case, you are attempting to remove coins based on the roll of 4 dice.

33162.name: City Planning
33162.description:
A game for the piecepack.

Equipment:


1 piecepack
1 standard Go board with two sets of differently colored Go stones (white and black stones are assumed in these rules)
1 opaque bag or bowl from which to draw piecepack coins
Paper and pencil for score keeping


The little village of Fumblebuck, Iowa, is in trouble. It’s currently a small village, but the population is booming and the rich resources of the area are bringing industry and commerce. The mayor of Fumblebuck decides to hire a pair of city planners to help plan and control the growth of his budding metropolis. The city planners know that the one who successfully brings the most balanced development to Fumblebuck will be assured of a long and lucrative political career in the region. So they set about zoning the county for development.

The players are the city planners hired to develop Fumblebuck. They compete with each other to create the best-supported Residential, Agricultural, Commercial, and Industrial zones in which businesses and families can thrive. The game progresses from a relatively unstructured growth in population and resource development in the area of town (placing Go stones on the board), through the establishment of various zones for constraining land usage (placing piecepack tiles on the board), to bringing new businesses, industries, and housing developments to town (placing piecepack coins on the board).

33163.name: City Council
33163.description:
A game for the piecepack.

Equipment:

* 1 piecepack
* 50 pennies
* 1 City Grid (included with the rules)
* 1 Turn Order/Action sheet (included with the rules)
* 3-4 Player Aid sheets (included with the rules)
* pencil(s) and paper for scoring, and clear tape

Welcome to the groundbreaking of a new city! Players will develop the new community through adroit manipulation of zoning and transit laws and important city councilors. The player who does this best wins the game.

33164.description:
It’s nice to spruce up the Christmas tree with light even if your brothers and sisters are a little competitive about it. This year you’ll show them how to do it right.

To play you will need to print out the game sheet and have a different colored pencil or crayon for each player. The board represents a Christmas tree the bulbs on it and the wires that join them.

On his turn a player will do one of two things -- 1) Color in any bulb not already part of a string of lights or 2) Continue a string of lights. This is done by coloring in a wire from a bulb of your color to another unclaimed bulb coloring it in.

Continue until there are no more bulbs to be claimed. Then the tree is scored -- one point for each bulb, one point for each wire.
33164.name: Christmas Lights

33165.name: Choosy Sushi
33165.description:
A changing landscapes game for the piecepack.

You are a waiter at Choosy Sushi, a very busy (and often times chaotic) sushi restaurant. Customers will make their orders, and it is your job to pick up the exact order off of the conveyor belt and deliver the food the fastest.

That would be easy, if the conveyor belt would just cooperate with you.

Be the first to get four dishes on your tray & deliver your food.

33166.name: Chemin Montagneux
33166.description:
A Changing Landscapes game for piecepack.

Once upon a time, four civil engineers decided to hike up and down a famous mountain range in France. Unfortunately, they were better engineers than they were hikers, so they tried to make the adventure more interesting by terra-forming the rough mountainous ground into gently sloping paths. Using shovels, pickaxes and dynamite, the engineers slowly turned the mountain range into a beautifully sculpted landscape. Now, you can recapture the glory of those original engineers as they struggled to conquer the mountains.

Trail-blaze a path and be the first to hike your way to the top of your own mountain peak. In the basic version of this game, no player can attempt to climb his peak until all peaks are visible. Once all four peaks are visible, players hike toward their particular peak. The winner is the first player who reaches his peak during his hike.

33167.name: Chaos Cruisers
33167.description:
A Changing Landscapes game for the piecepack.

In the far future, ordinary racing has become obsolete. The fans have grown bored with driving around in loops at high speeds. So, a new genre of racing is born—the Chaos Cruiser. These unique hover-vehicles are designed for pure speed and maneuverability. And they’ll need every bit of it because the racetrack is not what it seems. The track is made up of individual modules that shuffle about, ratcheting up the difficulty. Also, each driver has radio-controlled drones that can be placed as obstacles in their opponents’ paths. In the midst of all this chaos, one wily cruiser will prove to be the fastest, most agile, and most crafty of them all. Who will earn the Chaos Cup?

The piecepack tiles are laid out, so as to create a racetrack. Each player controls one cruiser, represented by a piecepack die. The number that is face-up on the die designates the speed of that cruiser. The coins have two uses. The null and ace coins are placed on the track as impassible obstacles. The 2, 3, 4, and 5 coins are used as nitro-boosts or shock-breaks, which greatly increase or decrease your speed. The pawns stand for the gates along the course. When a cruiser enters the tile containing a gate, he checks that gate off on the race progress chart. When all the cruisers have reached a certain gate, a chaos round is initiated, in which each player can move the two obstacles of his color. Also, the player in last place can move 3 tiles of the racetrack to entirely new locations. The first player to complete the race by passing through each of the four gates twice in the correct sequence is the winner.

33168.name: Truth Tower
33168.description: This game has solid wood playing pieces. It's very similar to Jenga. The difference is this game has a question printed on every block. The questions are like those that you ask in "truth or dare", although all of these are "truth" questions. Examples on the box are: describe yourself in three words, what is your biggest pet peeve, and who would play you in a movie of your life?

33169.name: The Wrong Game
33169.description: The box says: If you love a fast, furious, fun filled game that bends your mind, then The Wrong Game is the right game for you. Beat the clock as you answer all five questions fired at you with deliberately wrong answers. That's right... the more answers you get wrong, the more you get right. And if you draw a right/wrong card the game gets really crazy as you alternate between right and wrong answers. Welcome to the game where being wrong is oh so right!

33170.name: Solaria
33170.description:
It is the “Year of Unification” 01 in the star system Solaria, and aliens from all planets celebrate the beginning of a new era of peace and prosperity!

From the neophyte interplanetary capital on Luna, moon of Prime, to the local governments on the five planets, the newly united races of the Solaria system seek to spread their influence and control the fragile system-wide bureaucracy. As the leader of your race, can you build support on the planets, wisely assign your Councilors, and seize power as the Emperor of Solaria?

Solaria features area control, limited actions and resource management. The main action plays out on the five planets that rotate around the sun in different orbits. The ever changing rotation of the planets can dramatically affect game play, as planet position determines travel costs (the greater the distance between planets, the more fuel it takes to get there), scoring (elections only take place when a planet is in the same sector as the capital), and deep space exploration.

By winning elections, players appoint their Councilors to positions in the Solarian government that can best serve their own race (different assignments reap game-altering benefits). Competition for privileges is fierce. Choosing where to increase your power base on the planets, where to move your Planetary Base, whether to mine asteroids or the best method to explore deep space (and other options) is a careful balance of managing money, Councilors, and your rivals’ best-laid plans.

After six rounds, all planets hold their final elections. The player who exerts the most influence in the government becomes the Emperor of Solaria and wins the game!

Actual playing time is 90-150 minutes.

Note: The game was selected for participation in the 2008 Hippodice international game design competition. It is currently unpublished.

33171.description:
A game played with Icehouse pieces.

Equipment:

* 10 stashes of Icehouse pieces, in all of the different colors that are available as of the date of this revision (black, purple, blue, cyan, green, yellow, orange, red, clear, and white)
* 2 ten-sided dice (preferably ones with single-digit faces rather than the “tens” faces)

In this game of controlled chaos, the players compete to capture all ten colors of pieces.

The object of the game is to capture one each of all ten colors of pieces by pointing attackers at defenders (which are much like the attackers and defenders in Icehouse) in one of the four colors that each color of attacker is able to attack.

Whenever an attacker is placed such that it points at a defender in one of the four colors that the attacker is able to attack, the player who placed that attacker captures a piece corresponding to the color of the defender by taking the largest available piece of that color from the linear array of pieces.

The game ends when one player has successfully captured one piece in each of the ten colors of pieces. That player wins.
33171.name: Chaos

33172.description:
From the publisher:

Monastery is a tile laying game in which players construct different parts of a medieval monastery. The work is done by the monks of a player. The monks may move from tile to tile and in addition to building work they can also study, toil or pray. In the ‘icon’ game monks can also make use of the special properties of some of the tiles.

The tiles vary in value ranging from 1 point field and path tiles to 5 point Chapter House and Library. The higher the value of tile the more monks are needed to build it. Players can build independently, but often they are required to work collaboratively.

The game spreads over two days of monastic life, with turns being allocated as time for study and toil or for services in the abbey. At each service a new abbot is elected and apart from going first in the turn the abbot also has some significant powers.

In order to win the game players must collect the letters of the abbey’s motto ‘Libera Nos Quaesumus Ab Omnibus Malis Amen’. The letters become progressively more expensive and players must decide whether to buy letters or recruit extra monks.

Points at game end are also awarded for the ‘blessings’ which players can collect throughout the game.
33172.name: Monastery

33173.name: Tocapus
33173.description:
The fabled gold of the Incas lures. It's going to be an exciting treasure hunt. Treasure hunters with their scouts lead us through the maze. On the way, there are several sites with many treasures to discover.
The first player who reaches the end of the maze wins and will get the main treasure.

33174.name: Älypää!
33174.description: Älypää! is based on the most popular Finnish internet trivia game. At first you'll have to estimate to how many multiple choice questions you can answer correctly. Each correct answer brings you points and reaching your estimate gives you a bonus. The questions are of three different difficulty levels and in the beginning you're answering easy questions and in the end the really hard ones. During the game you can once skip answering a question, once delete a wrong answer choice and once ask for a clue. The board has two sides: On one side the winner is the player who has given most correct answers, on the other side the winner is decided by points.

33176.name: Pölkkypäät
33176.description: There are always nine heads on the board. Each turn one pf the players switches the places of two heads while other players are not looking. Afterwards the others try to memorize which two heads have changed places.

33177.name: Jungle Super Ball
33177.description: There are four animals; a lion, an elephant, a hippo and a giraffe; and in between the four there is a round field. The animals are trying to defend their own goals as the balls are swinging around the field. If you're able to defend your goal for a round you get a banana. The first player to collect four bananas is the winner. You can add a monkey referee to the game to make it more complex.

33178.name: Kummitusjuttu
33178.description: Find and collect bats in the ghost castle but beware the sun. At the same time try to get to know where the three little ghosts are. If you're the one to locate the ghosts first you'll win the round and are therefore able to trade your bats to building components of the castle. The first player to get six different components is able to build his tower ready and wins. The name of the game means ghost story.

33179.name: Ötökkäjahti
33179.description: The players are trying to get rid of their chips. The dice are rolled, one showing a color and the other a type of a bug. The player who first puts his chip on a tile matching to both the dice gets rid of a chip. The first player to get rid of all of his chips is the winner. The name of the game means bug hunt.

33180.name: Die drei ???: Das Geheimnis der Geisterinsel
33180.description:
The game to the movie:

Die Drei ??? Das Geheimnis der Geisterinsel
"The Three Investigators and the Secret of Skeleton Island"

Once again the three investigators are confronted with a mystery: the sinister ghost Tokolosh walk abroad a cave on the Skeleton Island. But is it truly a ghost? And what has the legacy of princess Lufefe to do with this?

You have to help the three investigators Justus, Peter and Bob to disclose the secret of skeleton island. Only the brave will enter the cave of Tokolosh and can then find all important clues, to start the chase and catch the suspected person.

33181.name: Williamsburg 1862
33181.description: Williamsburg 1862 is a small, brigade-level, low complexity game. Elements of the rule system include 1) a random selection (chit-pull) system, and 2) a simplified "orders system" that requires players to plan their operations in advance.

boardgamehonor: 2007 Årets Spil Best Children's Game Winner
33182.description:
"The Crazy Coconut Grabbing Game"

An Action/Dexterity game for two players; best played on the floor. Special mallets are used to whack the base of a coconut tree. The monkey "gets mad" and throws down coconuts. Players rush to collect the coconuts by bashing them with the mallets. When struck correctly, the coconut is sucked into the mallet. The player with the most coconuts at the end is the winner. Purple coconuts are worth double.

Contents:
16 coconuts, 2 mallets, coconut tree.

For ages 3+
Some assembly required.
33182.name: Monkey Madness

33183.name: Shaken Up
33183.description:
From the Babooshik Website
Shaken Up!™
The Intoxicating Dice Game

Get the party rolling! Shake up your next shindig with this push-your-luck dice game. Roll combos and "make drinks" to score, but watch out — one of your friends might steal it all! How’s that for a little controversy cocktail?

Shaken Up is the perfect mixer. Shake the ‘dice cubes’ high and low in the exquisite stainless steel martini shaker. If you make 2-pairs, full-houses, or 4-of-a-kind you can add scoring chips to the pot, but to bank those chips you’ll have to decide if you’re a martini or a margarita drinker and then make your drink. Feeling lucky? Try to tie-one-on or roll the garnish parade to scoop the pot.

Game Components:

Real Cocktail Shaker Container (game stores inside)
Shaker Cup
5 Cocktail Dice
3 Combo Coasters
6 Drink Maker Markers
42 Scoring Chips
Rules

33184.name: Tutankhamon (en busca de la civilización)
33184.description:
Game where the players make excavations in Egypt to find treasures of the Egyptian civilization.
Casuga Guina published two games.

33185.description:
Wings of War - Eagles of the Reich Squadron Pack contains maneuver and airplane cards for Wings of War: The Dawn of World War II.

Wings of War - Eagles of the Reich concentrates on Messerschmitt Bf 109 E series planes. It contains 18 new airplane cards and three B maneuver decks.

Part of the Wings of War series.
33185.name: Wings of War: Eagles of the Reich Squadron Pack
boardgamefamily: Wings of Glory / Wings of War

33186.name: Dash-in Dungeons
33186.description:
Dash-in Dungeons uses custom-designed cards to provide a fast-play, rules-light, portable, fantasy adventure game which can be played in around an hour.

The players cooperate as a small team of wizards and warriors exploring a dungeon map comprised of cards representing 'rooms/areas' where they encounter monsters, traps and treasures.

As the team explores the dungeon, the 'Dealer' reveals the map by flipping-over each new dungeon room card and reading the description from the 'Adventure key'. The players then decide what they want their characters do according to the rules (printed on quick reference cards).

Actions attempted, and combat with monsters is resolved using a set of 'Task rules' and the 'Fate deck' - a weighted set of numbered cards used to generate random numbers determining success or failure.

As the characters defeat a dungeon's challenges, they gather treasure cards representing 'gold' (to spend at the market between adventures) or 'magical devices' which enhance their abilities.

A team of players who plays more than one adventure together select character cards of increasing power level equipping their characters for the challenges offered by subsequent 'higher-level' adventures.

Home Page: http://www.dashindungeons.com

33187.name: Buzz Off: The Electronic Bingo Game
33187.description:
Buzz Off is Bingo with an electronic element. From the box cover: "You pick the winning number. Be careful! Trip the buzzer & you lose your turn."

Contents: six 5x5 bingo cards, one hundred chips (#1-25, four each), one bowl and base.

33189.description:
The players are hunting the evil robot Gobbot (played by another player) with four mini submarines within the human body. Goal is to catch the robot while spending as little energy as possible. Rules suggest that each players gets to play as the robot once, and then the scores are added.

Each turn, the players first choose an action card. There are cards which cost a different amount of energy (victory points); they cause the evil player to give more or less precise information about his current hiding place. Another type of card leads to some dexterity/sports contest between the evil and one of the good players; if good wins, they can make a guess where the robot is now.

After this, the players move their submarines; but they are restricted in the paths they may use.
Then the robot moves; he may use all paths, but can never return to a place he was before, which limits his moves as the game progresses.

Game ends with a victory of good when the players reach the robot, when the robot has no legal move left, or when the players guess right after winning a dexterity challenge. The robot player wins if he survives until the action card deck is exhausted after 16 turns.
33189.name: Der kleine Medicus

33190.name: Wild West
33190.description: There are two roads to Dodge City, one red and one black; you can chose one of these roads to go to your destination. On your way to Dodge City you will win or lose money, visit the saloons and get in fights with bandits. The Cowboy who reaches the Mayor in Dodge City with a gold bag and the most money will win the game.

33191.name: Sealord Rule the waves
33191.description:
An Exciting Sea-battle game - where the weather can be more dangerous than your opponent.

Manoeuvre your fleet of galleons to capture your opponents sailing Admiral before you are caught yourself. You navigate your fleet on treacherous seas and are constantly threatened by unpleasant surprises.

Flow of play is simple. Each player have four ships. One of them has the admiral. Each player can, on his turn move one ship two spaces, attack adjacent enemy ships and let the admiral change the ship his on. You can only do this to adjacent ships in your own colour.
The player who sinks the opponent players ship with his admiral on it wins.

Contents:
1 game board
12 playing pieces 10 galleons, 2 Admirals
1 top compass
1 point table
2 marker tags (small galleons)
1 black dice
1 white (wind) dice

33192.name: Scatz
33192.description:
SCATZ is a dynamic boardgame combining Blackjack and dice into a unique game. SCATZ, a fast-paced game in which tossing the dice determines your fate.
(From the box)

33193.name: Obol
33193.description:
Obol is a stimulating board game combining entertainment with education. Obol, an exciting addition game in which tossing the dice determines your numerical points. Obol is a dice game that challenges your mathematical skills.
(From the box)

33194.description:
The game was included in "Das Buch der Spiele" (Book of Games), a cataloge printed for Spielefest, Wien's game festival held on 23.-25.11.2007.

Players are trying to place their fish right way, so they score victory points (fish), while they cannot place white and black sheep near each other.
33194.name: Fische und Schafe

33195.name: Filibuster
33195.description:
The battle is for the treasure islands. You have to defend your own island and conquer your opponents island. On the boardgame you have tropical islands, reefs and treasure islands.

Filibuster is a loosely pirate-themed game where players take turns to move black and white plastic ships across a 13x13 square tile board. Apart from sea tiles there are skerry tiles (that cannot be entered), island tiles (which offer protection) and two treasure island tiles (which are the objectives of the game).

Each player has ten corvettes and three galleons at their disposal. Corvettes can land on islands but cannot sink other ships. Galleons, conversely, cannot land on islands but can sink an enemy ship by entering its tile at the end of a full 5-step move. The game ends when one player lands a corvette on the other player's treasure island.

Although there's no explicit art credit, the board bears the legend "Tegnestuen Den gyldne nøgle", Danish for "Studio The Golden Key", the firm name used by the Pagermans (professional artists both). The cover painting, however, showing generic pirate ships closing for battle, has a clipped, unreadable signature that doesn't seem to match either of their names.

33196.description:
In an age when poetry and the arts reigned supreme, the nights of Kyoto were filled with romance. Gentlemen of the Imperial court, ordinary clerks and functionaries by day, went out at night to meet their secret lovers in furtive trysts. Writing by the light of the moon, each tried to craft the finest and most moving poetry in the form of the Tanka, a short verse composed of only five lines. The best poems evoked the scene, the season, and represented the depth of the courtier's knowledge of the fashionable themes at court. By far, the most successful such lover was a fictional one named Hikaru Genji, the Shining Prince. Genji was, for the ladies of the court, the symbol of the perfect lover. For the men of the court, he was the perfect example to emulate.
In GENJI, players take the roles of courtiers out to woo fair princesses. Players score points for writing the finest poetry, or winning the most hearts. But beware: other courtiers will be waiting in the wings to steal those hearts away! Take your brush in hand, and set out on the night streets of Kyoto. The romance of the height of the Heian Period awaits you in GENJI.

Home Page: http://www.zmangames.com/cardgames/genji.htm

From BoardgameNews.com:

"Players in Genji try to learn from the historical figure of Genji and woo the ladies of the Imperial Court with their poetry. Twelve ladies, each bearing a symbol of one of the four seasons as well as one of three fashions – melancholy, nature, romance – are laid out in a circle, with a fashion card chosen at random to show players what type of poetry is in style.

"In each of the four seasons, each player will travel from his “home” – a lady chosen at the start of the game that bears his marker – around the circle in either direction. A player moves 1-3 spaces each turn, then either studies new material (discards poetry cards and draws new ones) or woos the lady he is currently visiting. If he has no rivals who have previously presented her with poems, he can present her with a poem on one or two cards. “Each poem card has the top or the bottom of a classic Tanka poem (5 lines, 5,7,5,7,7 syllables each, respectively),” says Kirk. “A poem can be considered either a top, a bottom, or a match of the two cards.”

"If another player has already presented a poem, then he can either complete the poem (assuming only a single card was played) or challenge it (by playing a poem card that increases the beauty of the poem, thus revealing the other player for the poser he is). In the latter case, you discard your contribution and the matching half, then add the remaining half poem to your hand to be used later.
...
"The round ends once a player returns home and makes a final study or woo action. Players then score points if they have the most poems on the board for that season, have presented the most beautiful poem of the season, or pitched woo at the home of another player. Yes, being a scoundrel can pay off."
33196.name: Genji
boardgamefamily: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

33197.name: Trybiki
33197.description:
(ENG) Cogwheels is a 2-person abstract strategy game, where using standard 6-sided dice guarantee balance of the game, as well as random factor. A single game lasts for about 10-20 minutes. The object of the game is controlling square consisting of 4 fields by your checkers. The characteristic of Cogwheels allows each player to move, or even pusch away the checkers in circles.

(DE) Trybiki (Zahnräder) ist ein abstraktes 2-Personen-Strategiespiel, bei dem die zufälligen Vorgaben eines Würfels taktisch klug genutzt werden müssen. Ziel ist es, auf dem Spielfeld alle vier Felder um ein Zahnrad herum mit eigenen Spielsteinen zu besetzen. Klingt einfach? Weit gefehlt! Die Zahnräder bringen nämlich Leben auf das Spielbrett und stellen die Spieler vor große Herausforderungen. Kaum zu glauben? Probier es aus! [Text auf der Schachtel]

(PL) Trybiki to abstrakcyjna gra strategiczna dla 2 osób, w której gracz musi mądrze wykorzystać wartości wyrzucane na kostce. Twoim celem jest zajecię własnymi pionkami wszystkich 4 pól wokół dowolnego trybiku. Łatwizna, powiesz... Niezupełnie! Trybiki sprawiają, że plansza żyje własnym życiem, a sama gra staje się ciekawym wyzwaniem. Nie wierzysz? Sprawdź sam! [Tekst z pudełka]

33198.name: Osada
33198.description: Osada ("The Settlement") is a game of development. Players develop their regions from simple and poor settlements to powerful and rich cities acquiring gold and other resources and building constructions like castles, mints, barracks, ports, cathedrals or universities. They can attack each other - and they can be attacked - thus they are able to recruit armies. The key to victory is to balance the economic and military development to achieve final supremacy over other players.

33199.name: Wild West: The Gunfight Game
33199.description:
A miniature wargame-like game where each player controls a character, moves around on a town street and tries to shoot the opponents.

All components (characters, street and houses) are paper based, except for some plastic chits.

A separate board is used to control loading etc of gun. Actual shooting occurs with dice rolling and card drafting.

33200.name: Quid
33200.description:
New trivia game containing 1500 questions from the Quid encyclopedia. Be the first to go from one end of the board to the other by answering questions about numbers, celebrities, hobbies, ...
Each card contains two questions, one for junior players and one for adult players, so that it can be played with all the family.

33201.name: Snarfquest Expansion 1 (Suthaze)
33201.description:
An expansion for the first edition of Snarf Quest.

This expansion pack includes 20 cards (2 each of 10 new card designs) including the evil wizard Suthaze, also provided as a miniature.

Available with blue, black, white, red or yellow borders.

Expands:

Snarf Quest

33202.name: Snarfquest Expansion 2 (Telerie)
33202.description:
An expansion for the first edition of Snarf Quest.

This expansion pack includes 20 cards (2 each of 10 new card designs) including the fighter-babe Telerie, also provided as a miniature.

Available with blue, black, white, red or yellow borders.

Expands:

Snarf Quest

33203.name: Snarfquest Expansion 3 (Aveeare)
33203.description:
An expansion for the first edition of Snarf Quest.

This expansion pack includes 20 cards (2 each of 10 new card designs) including the robot Aveeare, also provided as a miniature.

Available with blue, black, white, red or yellow borders.

Expands:

Snarf Quest

33204.name: Snarfquest Expansion 4 (Raffendorf)
33204.description:
An expansion for the first edition of Snarf Quest.

This expansion pack includes 20 cards (2 each of 10 new card designs) including the transformed prince Raffendorf the Rat, also provided as a miniature.

Available with black, blue, white, red and yellow borders.

Expands:

Snarf Quest

33205.name: Snarfquest Miniatures Bonus Pack
33205.description:
An expansion for the first edition of Snarf Quest.

Includes all the miniatures (Snarf in five different poses, plus Telerie, Suthaze, Aveeare, and Raffendorf) and ten bonus cards never seen in any other pack!

Available with blue, black, white, red and yellow borders.

Expands:

Snarf Quest

33206.name: Kaiser's Pirates: Expansion Pack
33206.description:
The pack includes 4 cards featuring historical British ships that saw action against the actual Kaiser’s Pirates.

8 New and Unique Action Cards

2 Team Play Cards
2 Reaction Cards
4 "British Forces" Cards

Expands:

The Kaiser's Pirates

33207.name: Blitzstreig
33207.description:
An abstract strategy game using metal figures or card discs representing aircraft, missiles, tanks, field guns, and different infantry troops. The gameboard has a grid of squares, on which each piece moves one square per turn.

The box describes it as a game of 'War Chess'. Each type of piece has a different range of pieces that it can take (by moving on to its square, as in Chess), and which pieces can take it.

Produced in New Zealand. Stated to be 'Ages 8 and up'.

33208.name: What?
33208.description:
From the publisher:

What?
WHAT A PARTY! WHAT A LAUGH! WHAT A THING TO SAY! WHAT A GAME.
About the Game

• Ages 14 and up
• 5+ Players

WHAT is a hilarious party game of who-said-what. Players are asked to write responses to humorous questions and situations, and everyone must guess who wrote what.

There is no need to be truthful!!! There is no need to be tasteful!!! Feel free to be as silly or as funny as you want… honesty is not the best policy in this game. WHAT is the perfect game for get-togethers and parties!

Contents

• 162 Cards
• Answer Sheet pad
• Scoring Sheet pad
• Scoring Sheet shield
• 12 pencils

33210.name: Sus-Pense
33210.description:
Sus-Pense is not just the game of "Hangman" but can also be used to play "The Game of Merrio" - a "Cootie" like game.

Sus-Pense has a man made of out plastic parts that you hang on a metal trapeze.

"A game of Wits for the Entire Family"

33212.description:
Maxi Zicke Zacke Hühnerkacke is a giant verson of Zicke Zacke Huhnerkacke (Chicken Cha Cha Cha) that incorporates costumes as part of the play. Children become the giant chickens that chase each other around oversized tiles to collect each other's tail feathers. Game play is the same as Zicke Zacke Hunerkacke with the exception that the kids are the chickens.

Available as a special order item from Zoch.

This game is part of The Chicken Family of Zoch.
33212.name: Maxi Zicke Zacke Hühnerkacke

33213.name: SIMSOC
33213.description:
SIMSOC (pronounced sim'-sock), a unique social process game, was developed to make social science more vivid than has been possible with traditional teaching methods. It is designed to be played WITHOUT the use of a computer. SIMSOC is a way to actively involve students in processes of large-scale conflict, protest, social control, and social change. SIMSOC creates a situation in which the participants must actively question the nature of social order.

Included are: Rules for playing, materials needed for play and questions to guide discussions afterward. Materials are provided on perforated sheets and include: SimBucks of various denominations, travel passes, sustenance tickets, and coupons which can be exchanged for "munchies" during the game (representing luxuries). Also included are play-aids, scenario leaflets and several puzzle sheets that are distributed to players as wage-earning jobs.

Players are citizens of a simulated modern international society taking on roles of political and industrial leaders, workers, the media, the judiciary and the unemployed. Some randomly selected players may be "Minorities" (wearing masks or armbands) and can be victims of prejudice at any time by the other players. Players attempt to deal with scenarios presented each session while attaining personal goals and maintaining a viable society.

SIMSOC is best with approximately 40 participants, and is intended to be played in 5 to 10 sessions of about an hour apiece. Rules adjustments are included to support smaller groups and fewer, abbreviated sessions. Space should be available to divide the players into 4 groups (or 3 for smaller games) preferably in separate rooms, although corners of a large room will suffice.

33214.name: Touring Scotland
33214.description:
An entirely new map game requiring skill and judgment.

Exciting, interesting, and educative.

A competitive game for 2-4 players in which the chief cities and towns are visited.

Object

Each player is dealt eight cards (two of each color).

The player arranges the cards, so as to form a journey by the shortest route, starting and finishing at the nearest large town to where the players live, or to where the game is being played. Players then set off on their journeys. Along the way watch out for collisions, traffic lights, and ferries!

Corresponding numbers on the cards and towns to be visited are given, to enable very young children to easily identify their route.

The winner is the first person to have visited their eight towns and returned home.

Contents:

1 playing board
32 cards in 4 colors
4 metal cars
1 die
1 wooden dice shaker
rules

33215.name: Finger Twister
33215.description:
[From Publisher]

Anytime, anywhere for a competition!!

Contents:
- Twister Mat
- Spinner Board and Arrow
- Nail Stickers

How to Play
1) Rotate the spinner board by turns.
2) The arrow indicates your appointed fingers and colored circle.
3) Follow the arrow indication, put your finger on the appropriate colored circle.
4) The last player left in the game is the winner!

Note: In any condition, whoever cannot put their finger on an appropriate colored circle will lose.

To make the game more fun and exciting, put the favorite color stickers on your nails from the included stickers.

[From submitter tonyfung1205]
It's a mini variant from the twister line. This game is particularly designed for two players only in a handy competition. The game board is about 5.5 inches x 5.5 inches. The small sized game board makes the game can be played on ship, on rail, or even at a restaurant.

I got this piece of game in Hong Kong, with bilingual instructions (English and Chinese).

33216.description:
A fun childrens game that trains both the memory and their portraying skills. Cards are face down, acting as a memory, when your turn, you have to portray the animals gesture drawn on the card(s). The drawings are very cute, and so are the kids acting them out..

Very simple game setup, lots of fun for smaller kids. or....

Also loads of fun on a late night with family or friends that had just a little to much to drink ! (hence my Party game entry)
33216.name: Lari Safari

33217.name: My First Huisje Boompje Beestje
33217.description:
Pachisi for the smaller players that can't read or write yet.
All players move around the same board, so they may capture each others pawns. Captured pawns are returned to their player's corner and must start their journey over. The winner is the first player to move all pawns "home".

The numbers on the dice are replaced by 6 symbols: House, Animal, Tree, Tulip, Appel & Car.
Player gets to move his/her pawn forward to the indicated/thrown symbol.
Gameplay start after throwing a 'House'

33219.name: Pohjoisen Pikajunan Arvoitus
33219.description:
The board is map of Finland with not entirely accurate railway and bus network. One of the players is the mystery traveler who plans his/her route from on of three cities in southern Finland (Turku, Helsinki or Kouvola) to one of the three towns in northern Finland (Kolari, Rovaniemi or Keminjärvi) and back. He/she only reveals his/her whereabouts in every sixth city he/she visits.

If the mystery traveler can make his/her route, he/she is the winner. If any of the other players can get to the same city with the mystery traveler that player wins.

Players move by throwing dice and completing tasks in cities they visit. Mystery traveler doesn't throw dice.

This game is a promotional game from the Finnish transport company VR.

33220.name: Seafood Palace
33220.description:
Seafood Palace is a medium-weight resource management and auction game for three to five players aged 10 years and older. Games usually last from 60 to 90 minutes. The game features an innovative dice drafting mechanism for players to obtain resources used in bidding for cards which yield points. Each turn, players have a variety of actions available to them and tempo is an important consideration – it may be good to get a bid in first to win a card cheaply, but at the cost of taking a high value die instead.

In Seafood Palace, players take on the role of Chinese seafood restaurant owners in Singapore, seeking to gain fame points by bidding to satisfy public demand for tasty seafood dishes. The more resources you put into the dish, the more likely that people will identify that dish with your restaurant, and this recognition is represented by fame points.

Every player starts with stores of fish, prawn, crab, non-seafood resources (chicken and vegetable), beverages and coins. The resources are represented by counters on the player’s own board, which represents the player’s stores.

Each round, public demand is represented by dish cards that become available for auction. Players bid to satisfy the demand with the corresponding resources and the highest bid wins the card and the fame points on the card.

Each round, new resource dice and number dice are available for players to replenish stores. These dice are traded in as pairs (one of each kind) to get the specified number of the specified type of resource (e.g. a 5-number die and a crab resource die are traded in for 5 crab resources).

There are also bonus cards which could permit special actions to benefit the player - some of the bonus action cards include discounts on buying seafood resources, using MSG to get an advantage over your competitors (but with a penalty) or the abundant catch that helps you stock up on seafood. Bonus cards could also be set menus, which if fulfilled by the end of the game, will yield bonus points. A wedding banquet menu is valuable, and this game also caters to vegetarians with a vegetarian set menu. If you hire a master chef, your lowly 1-point dishes will increase in value.

The twist is that players have to choose which of several actions they want to take (take a die, bid on a dish, claim a dish, bid on a bonus card, claim a bonus card, or pass) and focusing on one action means sacrificing the tempo to carry out another action. If you decide to go for the high number die, someone else could take the resource die of the type you need badly, and yet another will get in a bid on a valuable card that you can’t outbid because you haven’t managed to obtain the right dice yet …

The game lasts enough rounds so that each player has the advantage of going first an equal number of times. At the end of the game, players score fame points for dish cards they have won, set menus they have fulfilled with their dishes, and recognition for having the best stocked cellar (player with the most beverages) and best seafood stocks (player whose least seafood resource is greater than other players’ least seafood resource). The player with the most famous restaurant wins.

Seafood Palace was accepted for play-testing in the 2008 Hippodice competition

33221.name: Crazy Dice Math
33221.description:
A learning Math game from CB Publishing.

Includes:
2 Glow in the Dark 6 sided dice
1 Glow in the Dark 12 sided dice (special sides)
1 Instruction Book.

The book contains 10 games for 2 or more players. Each game is a simple dice game to help with math skills.

Ages 7 and up.

33222.description:
This is Moscow Attacked's smaller and simpler "little brother" (about the Battle of Moscow in late 1941)

Map scale: 100 kms per hex
Time scale: 1 turn = 20 days
Units: 14 ground and air units for the Germans and 16 for the Russians.

The game is available for FREE at http://LCoat.tripod.com/MoscDef.htm
33222.name: Moscow Defended
